message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) IIa, which is characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. The elevated calcitonin and PTH levels, as well as the presence of adrenal lesions, support this diagnosis. FMTC is a subtype of MEN II and does not typically involve adrenal lesions. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a syndrome associated with multiple types of cancer but does not typically involve endocrine tumors. MEN IIb is also a subtype of MEN II but is characterized by the presence of mucosal neuromas, as well as medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma. The absence of mucosal neuromas in this patient makes MEN IIb less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a thyroid nodule that moves with swallowing, along with hypercalcemia and elevated levels of calcitonin and PTH, suggests multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) IIa. The bilateral adrenal lesions also support this diagnosis. FMTC and MEN IIb also involve the thyroid but do not typically involve the adrenal glands. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to certain types of cancer but is not associated with the specific symptoms and findings described in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest hyperparathyroidism, and the diagnostic imaging shows bilateral adrenal lesions, which suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) IIa. FMTC only involves the thyroid gland, and Li-Fraumeni syndrome and MEN IIb involve mutations in different genes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and findings suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type IIa, which is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. The elevated calcitonin and PTH levels and the bilateral adrenal lesions support this diagnosis. The other options do not include all of these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a nodule on the anterior portion of the neck that moves with swallowing, which is classic for thyroid nodules. The hypercalcemia, elevated calcitonin, and adrenal lesions suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type II. Men type II have a mutation in the RET gene, and there are two subtypes: MEN IIa and MEN IIb. FMTC is also associated with a mutation in the RET gene but is characterized by thyroid nodules only. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a predisposition to cellular mutations but is not associated with the specific symptoms presented by the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a thyroid nodule, and the lab results and diagnostic imaging indicate hyperparathyroidism and adrenal lesions, which are consistent with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) IIa. None of the other options involve these specific findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a nodule on the anterior portion of the neck that moves with swallowing, hypercalcemia, elevated calcitonin, and an inappropriately elevated PTH level all indicate a potential thyroid or parathyroid issue, potentially related to a multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. The presence of adrenal lesions also supports a MEN diagnosis, and specifically MEN type IIa, which involves medullary thyroid cancer, parathyroid adenomas/hyperplasia, and pheochromocytoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a nodule on the anterior portion of the neck that moves with swallowing, elevated calcitonin and PTH, and bilateral adrenal lesions suggests Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) IIa, which is characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is associated with a predisposition to multiple types of cancer, but not necessarily endocrine tumors. FMTC involves only the thyroid gland and does not typically include other endocrine organs. MEN IIb includes medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma, but not hyperparathyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including hypercalcemia, elevated calcitonin, and elevated PTH, along with the presence of a nodule in the neck and bilateral adrenal lesions suggest Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) IIa. FMTC would only involve thyroid cancer, while Li-Fraumeni syndrome and MEN IIb are associated with other types of cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) IIa is the most likely diagnosis, which includes medullary thyroid cancer, hyperparathyroidism, and pheochromocytoma. The presence of a nodule on the anterior portion of the neck that moves with swallowing, accompanied by mild lymphadenopathy, supports medullary thyroid cancer. Elevated calcitonin and PTH levels and bilateral adrenal lesions on imaging also support MEN IIa. Li-Fraumeni syndrome and FMTC do not typically present with these symptoms.
